intro: Nigella truncata, commonly known as the Persian buttercup, is a flowering plant native to Central Asia and the Middle East. It is characterized by its basal rosette of hairy, dark green leaves and bright yellow flowers that bloom in early spring. The plant produces small, triangular seeds that are often used as a spice in various cuisines. Nigella truncata thrives in well-drained soil and full sun, making it a hardy perennial in temperate climates. Its botanical features make it both ornamental and useful in culinary applications.
